title: HUGE security flaw
body: So ever since the new launcher came out I have been quite a fan of it. However, that all changed when someone got access to my account. I'm not exactly sure how they did it but they managed to play multiple games on my account. Once I figured this out I changed my password immediately. I thought the problem was over and I didn't have to worry anymore. I quickly found out I was wrong. When I launched the game to enter my new password, It immediately sent me to the home screen. I thought it was a little odd at first so I waited to see if the password hadn't been updated yet. After hours of waiting it still just let me log in automatically without having to enter the new password. I changed my password again to see if it fixed it and once again, it did not ask me to enter my new password. The person who originally took of my account still has access and is still playing games and I have no way to get them off my account. I have emailed riot support however they seemed to ignore it and just prompt another password change. This is a huge security flaw and needs to be addressed immediately.

> [{quoted}](name=Terozu,realm=NA,application-id=LqLKtMpN,discussion-id=tHTMBxxb,comment-id=0000000000010000,timestamp=2019-11-14T15:04:00.277+0000)
>
> Passwords can be guessed super fucking easily on any platform not just league.  That's not something you can really help.


Of course you can - you can use more secure passwords.

There's really no such thing.

OoC what would you define as a secure password?

10+ characters with non-alphanumeric characters thrown in. If you're logging onto a system that doesn't allow non-alphanumerics, then the longer you make it, the better. Most login systems lock you out after enough failed attempts, and somebody being able to successfully guess a password of the length I mentioned with non-alphanumerics thrown in is next to impossible within the lockout attempt window. Alphanumeric characters give you a possibility of 36 characters per password character to choose from, add in non-alphanumerics and you get significantly more. 

Even if you were to take a general password, like the stereotypical "Password123," you could do "P[as]s/w-or=d1,2(3" and you've made it significantly harder to crack, even for a password that started off that simple. The only reliable way someone is getting that password is if they use a program to brute force passwords in a system that doesn't lock you out from repeated failed attempts, or decrypt the password database (which is a huge undertaking in and of itself), or scam it out of you.

*kfdj*#($ K# LL@#(#$ #DFDLdsafd#$(#@(sfaas#$))##_@_DFda#+$#++@$#+##+fdsaFDKJF:LKJDS(#($#(#$ (#O KEKRfafomegalulRK< $)#)#

If you make your password 5 letters long, yes. Every additional letter multiplies how hard it is to guess by the number of possible characters.

A LoL password can be up to 30 chars long, alphanumeric at the least, so a minimum of 36 possible chars.

According to the handy scientific calculator in windows, 30^36 is 1.50094635296999121e+53, which i wont write in normal notation because it is over 50 digits long. That is the number of possible passwords.

A decently long password with a scattering of non-alphanumeric is utterly impossible to guess even if the server does not lock out the account after multiple failures, which most do.

Basically all league "hacks" are because someone gave away their login info on some "Free RP" scam or had their email stolen in a similar fashion. Of course people rarely admit to something that moronic.

Relevant XKCD https://imgs.xkcd.com/comics/password_strength.png

You might want to try enabling two factor authentication. You will then be able to remove the player that's using your account from a trusted accounts list. https://support.riotgames.com/hc/en-us/articles/360010367273-Two-factor-authentication-FAQ
I'm not sure if this will solve the problem but I hope it does.

Two factor authentication is really the best way to make sure your account doesn't get hacked into. I understand why Riot doesn't force everyone to use it (Don't yall have phones??), but it really acts as that final gatekeeper.

The other thing you brought up is highly concerning. The fact that a password change isn't prompting the client to ask you to re-authenticate and enter the new password is a huge red flag. Sounds like they are just using a login token that never really expires.
If you haven't already, create a support ticket and highlight this. Someone guessing your password is one thing, having a password change not force users to enter the new password is definitely a bug (and security exploit)

At least you still have your account.   My friend lost his account because someone jacked it, hacked a bit and then Riot auto banned it, and refused to listen to him when he tried to get the account back and explained the situation.  

To be honest Riot is really really good at security and intelligent bans.
